section-block.rac_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell
section-block.rac_book_summary: A girl and her parents plan a hiking trip up Hickory Hill. They notice trees, plants, and animals along the way. They even meet a friendly toad. The family works together to get to the top.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about the four seasons. Focus on fall since that is the season they will see in Hiking Day.
Invite children to dance to the PreK On My Way™ theme music to build excitement for reading Hiking Day. Have them act out hiking.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Hiking Day written by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. Who can show me the name of the author? What does the author do?
Scout loves narratives about exploring nature. These stories help him learn about new places and things to do outside!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
How does the girl get ready for the hike up Hickory Hill?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl and her parents are going on an adventure today. They are about to climb Hickory Hill.
The family is getting ready for their hike. What does the girl put on first?
The family is trying to decide which of the different color paths they will take.
What color path did the family choose? Why did they choose that one?
What is the girl wearing on her head? Why do you think she is wearing it? What else is the girl doing?
What does the girl notice as she is climbing up the hill? Are the trees taller? How does she describe the ground?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
How does the girl get ready for the hike up Hickory Hill?
section.rac_body-text: Give one moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about taking a long walk somewhere interesting as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the girl put on?
Why does the girl fill her water bottle?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Many stories depend on children’s knowledge of the four seasons that occur in many parts of the United States. Some children may not understand that some leaves change colors in the fall. They may not know how animals like chipmunks prepare for the winter. Talk about the seasons and how animals prepare for different seasons.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Talk and Share
section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to talk and share their experiences about working together. Explain that when we work together we can get something done faster. When we work together, we need to listen to each other and be kind to each other. In Hiking Day, the girl and her parents work together to choose which trail to take up the hill.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk and share about working together as we revisit the book Hiking Day written by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell.
Clifford loves to talk and share about working together with his friends and family.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story to notice the talk and share Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How are the girl and her parents working together to plan their hike?
Let’s talk about what they planned to do first by looking at the map. (MB)
Why can’t the girl and her parents see the sky?
As they climb higher up Hickory Hill, they see a fat toad.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: What does the girl notice about the toad’s colors?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The family cannot find the red marker. The girl thinks they might be lost. Let’s talk and share about how the family works together to climb up the hill. (MB)
How can you tell that the family is going the right way?
Look closely. What animals do you see? Can you describe them?

section.rac_body-text: Have children practice working together with their peers to play “Animal Sounds.” Have each child choose to be a different animal and then make the sound the animal makes. The goal is to have children show that they know the sound each animal makes. Suggest animals for children who have a hard time thinking of animals to be. Make sure children know the sound we use in English for a dog and a cat. Each language uses its own sounds for animal sounds. For example, in English the rooster says cock-a-doodle-doo. In Spanish he says ququiriqui, and in French he says cocorico.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about working together with their friends.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage children to talk and share by asking questions that relate to the child’s experiences or interests. Add to what the child says and model new language. Make sure to give children enough time to respond to questions and to share their own experiences. (National Center for Quality Teaching and Learning, 2012)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that when you want to know about something, you ask questions.
Have children pretend that they are tall trees. Have them stretch their arms up high. Then ask them to move their branches (arms) and shake their leaves (fingers).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Hiking Day.
Scout loves Hiking Day because he likes narratives about nature and going for long walks.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What animals do the girl and her parents see as they climb Hickory Hill?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl says trails are like paths.
Do you agree? Why did they choose the red trail?
The first animal the girl sees says, “Ribbit, ribbit!” What animal says that?
Why does the girl think they might be lost? What do they need to find to know if they are on the red trail?
An animal is climbing up the tree. It’s hiding the red mark. What animal do you see?
What animal does the girl’s mother see? What is the animal doing? Why?
Where is the family now? Are they still in the woods?
How do you know?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
What animals do the girl and her parents see as they climb Hickory Hill?
section.rac_body-text: Give one moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to write about what the family sees along the trail. Invite children to use describing words.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What animal does the family see?
The family sees a prickly p_______ (porcupine).
The family sees a prickly porcupine.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Some animals, such as deer, may be familiar to children, even if they don’t know the English word. Other animals, such as porcupines, may be unfamiliar. Discuss each animal with children, noting the animal’s unique characteristics. Extend children’s vocabulary by discussing other animals children might find in the woods.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about working with friends or family to do something—for example, making food, walking the dog, etc.
Have children act out making a giant pot of soup. Have each child stand and choose a vegetable, and then walk over to the giant “pot” and drop it in. One child can stir.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read We Have Soup! It is a narrative in the form of a poster about rabbits who work together to make a delicious soup.
Scout loves narratives about friends working together.
Hiking Day and We Have Soup! are about how we can work together. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What can we do better together?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Big Idea
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the back of the Big Chart. Then use these prompts to read and discuss the story.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The rabbits are about to make soup.
Carlos and Clara are the first rabbits to bring a vegetable. They brought peas.
What color are the peas?
What do Larry and Brenda Rabbit bring for the soup?
How did the family in Hiking Day work together to plan their hike?
How did the rabbits work together in We Have Soup!?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to try to put together a puzzle alone for a few minutes. The puzzle should not have many pieces. Divide children into teams. Have them put the puzzle together as a team. Encourage children to communicate as they work together to complete the puzzle. Ask if it was easier to complete the puzzle as a team or alone.
Provide a writing prompt about working together and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write their responses to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning both English and Spanish words for vegetables might help children recognize words that are used at home. We say peas in English and chícharos in Spanish. We say corn in English and maíz in Spanish. We say carrots in English, and zanahorias in Spanish. Reviewing both can help emphasize the unique knowledge multilingual learners can bring.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children reenact the following scenes from Hiking Day: preparing for the hike by putting on sturdy shoes and a floppy hat, looking at the map together to decide which trail to climb, leaping like a toad or a deer, kneeling down to look at the toad; looking around for the trail marker, and reaching the summit of Hickory Hill.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Hiking Day written by Anne Rockwell and illustrated by her daughter Lizzy Rockwell.
Scout loves to read stories about characters who work together. The girl worked with her parents to reach the top of Hickory Hill, and the rabbits worked together to make a delicious soup!
As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What happens when they reach the top of Hickory Hill?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the girl say the ground is covered with?
Where are the girl and her parents in this illustration? Are they still at their house? Where are they? How do you know?
What animal do they see? What is the animal doing? Why?
A deer leaps away so fast that only the girl sees him.
Can you describe what the deer looks like?
The girl’s father says they are at the top of Hickory Hill. How can you tell that they reached the top?
What is the family doing now? What friendly animals do they see again?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question: What happens when they reach the top of Hickory Hill?
Have children Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They sit down on a sunny warm rock.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about something they have done with their friends or family.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What kind of rock do they sit on?
They sit on a w_____ (warm) rock.
They sit on a warm rock.
Why do you think the rock was warm?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage children to observe the natural world. Look closely at different shapes, sizes, and colors of leaves. Go outside with children. Encourage them to call out the animals they see. You can help them use a magnifying glass to observe non-poisonous insects they encounter outside.
